utterances: But first, we want to catch up with another story this week, the murder of a top official in Russia.
It has stirred memories of the 1990s, when contract killings were standard procedure for settling commercial disputes.
NPR's Gregory Feifer reports the latest murder has shocked the Russian political establishment.
Andrei Kozlov was the number two official in Russia's Central Bank.
Gunmen shot him in the head and chest in Moscow Wednesday night as he left a soccer game between bank employees.
He died of his wounds later in the hospital.
Politicians say the murder bore all the hallmarks of a contract killing.
Interior Minister Rashid Nurgaliyev told a televised cabinet meeting police had launched a major investigation.
(Through translator) Experienced organized crime investigators went to the scene right away.
I'm personally taking control of almost all investigations.
We're examining the possibility that the crime was tied to his professional activities, but there are other theories as well.
Kozlov had many enemies.
He'd led a serious effort to shut down banks suspected of money laundering and other crimes.
Forty-four banks were deprived of their licenses this year alone.
On Thursday, Prime Minister Mikhail Fradkov led a minute of silence before saying Russia's top officials are doing dangerous in a period of transition from communism.
(Through translator) We're trying to create a fair playing field for business in this country, but that's not always accepted by those who wish to have certain advantages and privileges.
Many officials have appeared on television to express outrage over Kozlov's murder.
Speaker of Parliament Boris Gryzlov, a former interior minister, said there was little doubt he was targeted for posing a threat to criminal groups.
(Speaking foreign language)
His work overseeing banks' activities, he said, could have prompted criminals in those banks to order the killing.
This month Kozlov had proposed permanently banning from banking anyone involved in money laundering.
The measure would end the common practice of re-registering banks under a new name.
Banker and former Finance Minister Mikhail Zadornov praised Kozlov for his dedication and spotless reputation.
(Through translator) The entire banking community believes Kozlov became a victim of his principles.
He steadfastly cracked down against banks' illegal activities.
Mikhail Grishankov, who chairs the Duma's Anti-Organized Crime Committee, said Kozlov was conducting extremely difficult work.
He said many Russian banks have links to organized crime and corrupt officials.
(Through translator) It's a very powerful multi-headed system.
Imagine, each year it's possible to launder tens of billions of dollars.
I don't fault a municipality from wanting those things.
But we have to be very mindful of the overall impacts.
Banking became one of Russia's dangerous professions in the 1990s, as the system emerged from the first wild years of post-Soviet capitalism.
Gunmen twice shot at a former Central Bank chief in 1990s, and five bankers were killed between 1995 and 1997.
Another prominent banker was murdered last year.
Analysts say Kozlov's killing represents a challenge for President Vladimir Putin, who has amassed huge powers by promising to crack down against crime and corruption.
They say corruption is rife in Russia, and that the murder should be a wakeup call for the government.
Gregory Feifer, NPR News, Moscow.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Robert Siegel.
Many Americans are not saving enough for retirement.
Most employers offer 401(k) savings plans, but many employees don't take advantage of them.
Well, now employers are trying to increase participation in these plans.
They are enrolling their workers in the plans automatically.
NPR's Wendy Kaufman reports.
For most American workers, their 401(k)s are their primary and often their only retirement fund; money's deducted from their paychecks before taxes and put into their account.
The term 401(k) comes from the section of the IRS code that created these savings plans.
Today, roughly 43 million Americans contribute to their 401(k); employers often match at least a portion of what workers put in.
Historically, employees had to specifically sign up for the payroll-deduction savings plan, but that was not the offer made to Brendan Stokeness(ph).
He's in his mid-20s and is a new employee at US Bank, a company which automatically enrolls employees in a 401(k).
I think it's just nice that it's set up automatically 'cause a lot of people won't take action and set it up themselves.
In fact, about 30 percent of those who could sign up don't, and that, says economist Sarah Holden, is why employers are switching to automatic enrollment.
Automatic enrollment changes the participation decision from opting in to opting out.
And so it's a really great thing because it makes the decision--if someone does nothing, they end up saving for retirement rather than not saving.

Holden, a researcher for the Investment Company Institute, a trade association for the mutual fund industry, says a household survey conducted a few years ago pointed to a number of reasons individuals don't set aside money in their 401(k).

Many said they couldn't afford to save right now; others said they were saving in other ways; still others said the enrollment process and the selection of investment options was simply too complex and confusing.
Again, Sarah Holden.
Automatic enrollment, really, actually helps with both the feeling that you can't save and the feeling that you don't know how to pick the options, because it puts you in and they tend to stay in.
Inertia is a powerful thing.
People in the plans tend to remain in the plans.
Today, nearly one in five large companies automatically enrolls its employees in a 401(k); that's a dramatic increase from just two years ago.
And when companies offer automatic enrollment, participation rates soar to 90 percent.
Even lower-wage and younger workers who often don't sign up for 401(k)s participate at very high levels.
Some companies are going one step further.
They are automatically increasing the amount that's deducted from employee pay and put into their savings plan.
As Lori Lucas of Hewitt Associates, a human resources consulting firm, explains, a worker might contribute 3 percent the first year, 4 percent the next year and so on, up to 6, 8, even 10 percent.
For the typical worker who really doesn't want to be that involved in managing their 401(k) plan on an ongoing basis, this program allows them to put it on autopilot.
Their contributions are increased over time, and their portfolio is managed on their behalf.
And how those portfolios are managed is also changing.
Historically, fund managers have invested 401(k) money very conservatively, in money market accounts or balanced fund accounts.
Now, says Lori Lucas, a majority of large firms are offering so-called `life-cycle funds,' which are pegged to a retirement date and morph over time.
And all you need to do as an employee or a participant in the 401(k) plan is pick which fund matches your time horizon.
The funds typically have the retirement date in their name.
So, for example, if you're planning to retire in 2030, you pick the 2030 fund.
Typically, these funds invest in equities when workers are young and automatically shift toward more conservative investments as workers get closer to retirement.
While all these automatic features have benefits, there is a potential downside, suggests David Wray, president of the 401(k) Council of America.
He says once employers start to make decisions for workers, the workers tend to let the employer make all the decisions forever, and that might not be in their best interest.
Mr.
DAVID WRAY (President, 401(k) Council of America): The employees will just stick with this employer-decided system right up until they retire.
And I think it's very important that at a minimum five years out from when they retire, they begin to customize their investment solution and their savings based on their particular needs.
For example, the default contribution amount set by many companies, typically about 3 percent, is quite a bit less than what higher-income workers generally contribute if they enroll on their own.
Participation in a 401(k) is voluntary.
Even with automatic enrollment, employees can opt out of the plan entirely, or they can skip the default options and pick their own contribution amounts and their own investment vehicles.
One man who's taking charge from the get-go is Brendan Stokeness.
The new US Bank hire we heard from earlier is already customizing his account, investing far more than the 2 percent the bank uses for its automatic enrollment.
A lot of people think about what they want now; they want a new car, they want nice clothes.
And I'm thinking about what I want when I'm 60.
So I'm kind of trying to set myself up for that retirement life, where if I want to work, I can; if I don't want to work, I don't have to.
I'm all right.
How are you, Riley?

Those sentiments are likely music to the ears of financial planners and policy-makers, who hope that automatic enrollment and the changes that have come with it will lead to a boost in the amount of money working Americans save.
Wendy Kaufman, NPR News.
